I've played through this game dozen and dozens of times and have to say how ground-breaking brilliant this game really is to play through. Its storyline, gameplay, graphics, NPCS, soundtrack, and sci-fi setting along with more really set up its place in the game making it a outstanding FPS games to play so far in gaming history. All of this efforts showed itself how breath-taking and hard it took the developers to make this which turned out highly good at the end. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's interested in playing it.

Thank you, Valve!

Still holds up as a solid single player FPS in 2022. Obviously shows some age, but the core gameplay is fun, movement is fluid and satisfying (albeit a little bit slippery), weapons are fun to use, enemies have decently good AI for 1998. I think I like it slightly more than Opposing Force, and quite a bit more than Blue Shift, though I recommend playing all three back-to-back for a solid 20 hours in the HL1 universe.

half-life

As good as it's cracked up to be, and as good today as it was in 1998. One of the more intelligent FPSs ever made with a wonderfully engaging story, well-executed gunplay and puzzles, and top-tier pacing. Provided that one can handle '98 graphics (& the visuals here are not ugly by any means-- quite the opposite, in fact!) then this is well worth a purchase and playthrough even 24 years later.

Played a little when I was young but really got into half life 2 on x box. That being said I said you know what let's try and do the first.....boy oh boy. The controls on movement is something else. Can barely get on a damn ladder cause you move so fast. Definitely have a pc set up with desk and all cause I had a hell of a time just trying to do the tutorial. With that I would rate this game 3 out of 10 donkeys. Just go play H.L 2 or something else

Full review at: https://thegamehoard.com/2022/04/28/50-years-of-video-games-half-life-pc/

The revolutionary intersection of character control and storytelling certainly helps emphasize the player‚Äôs agency in Half-Life, an idea that extends to area navigation as platforming and puzzles can utilize most of the available environment. That exploration can be strained at times due to limitations or harsh punishments for small mistakes, but allowing liberal use of the save system dampens such issues and the gun play between moments of navigation packs in plenty of enjoyable weapons and varied enemy types. The first-person shooting never stagnates during the story, and while the hectic multiplayer isn‚Äôt too appealing, the single player manages to curate plenty of distinct and engaging moments that mostly offset the rougher elements.
